posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Hey Val!

So many STR-based Assassins lately in the guild, both from you, me, but also campgod's one in the Build Request forums. I like the originality of the build with these classes, but I don't necessarily think it's the best possible choice for the build. First of all, the thing which sucks for all STR-based Assassins: You don't have much to choose from with the Bonus Feats that they give. You get SF only for Hide and Move Silently, Epic Reflexes, which is at least half-useful on a build with no Evasion. Secondly, you could get what you got from 5 Ranger levels with 2 more Fighter levels, and if you dropped 2 or 3 Assassin levels, you'd have plenty of room to maneuver and add a third class that would bring something to the mix. SD would give you HiPS and Evasion with just 2 levels, Monk would give you 7 Attacks Per Round, Rogue would give you Evasion with 2 levels and +1d6 of damage or even 2 if you take 3 Rogue levels, etc..

I do understand why you went with Ranger in this build, to avoid having to cross-class Hide and Move Silently to meet the Assassin's requirements with a full BAB class, and in that sense, that aspect adds finesse to the build, but at the same time, I don't think it brings anything else to the build other than the +1 BAB and Hide and Move Silently as class skills (which you could easily reach anyway cross-classing by dropping Spellcraft). It seems that, although quite well-built, this build doesn't exactly explore any synergies between the classes.

So, how do we make it synergetic? Well, as I stated in campgod's thread, the synergy between Ranger and Assassin lies in the dual-wield combination with Death Attack, adding one more attack to the first flurry when hasted and making the enemy roll another Fort save to avoid being paralyzed (a 33% increase on paralyzing chance). There are many ways to achieve that. Ranger 10 / Fighter 8 / Assassin 22 seems like a better spread to me. If you go with 4 Assassin pre-epic, you'll actually have the same number of epic feats, because you can go Fighter 7 Ranger 9 Assassin 4 for +1 BAB at the cost of either Luck of Heroes, Stealthy or Great Fortitude (I'd personally drop LoH). With that change, you'd also need a focus on lighter weapons to be able to dual-wield without the penatly, so Handaxes could work better. You lose a little bit of weapon damage, but you gain 2 more attacks per round and keenable weapons to crit more often as an offset to balance it out. I'm sure your damage per round will be higher. And with the BAB increase, you'll get only -1 to your build's AB from where it stands now for 2 extra attacks per round. You'd need to wear light armor, but that would mean a lower chance of detection. You would lower your DA DC by 3 (a 15% decrease in paralysis chance, so it's still a positive balance) and lose 2d6 of damage when Sneaking (but 4 attacks with 12 d6 of extra damage is still less than 6 attacks with 10d6 of damage). So, as you can see, the math here favors this alternative route by a lot. Otherwise, you'd be much better off just going for Rogue, to get the same die in SA, plus Evasion, access to Crippling Strike, ESF that can be applied to all skills, not just Hide and Move Silently, Slippery Mind, etc...

The reason to go with Assassin over Rogue are the spell-like abilities and the chance of paralysis, so for that, I believe you really need to invest in Ranger a bit more. Oh! And you'd gain 4 extra skill points with this tweak AND one more FE. now THAT should be enough to convince you! LOL

Take it EZ!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
A dwarven hitman - oh, so dwarven!
Sturdy and strong with high constitution, high fort saves, full plate, a skull-crusher weapon and full beard.
Versatile like "fighter-thieves" are supposed to be.
Even though you spend 5 feats to silence his clanking armor, I don't see this character as a stalker. He is more of a brawler and flanker with high strength, high constitution, undispellable SCV and IKD - He can even face foes toe to toe like the forefathers of his clan have done since long before legends and myths.
I like the uniqueness of the build, a dwarven hitman done the dwarven way. I also understand why you use ranger rather than SD, Ranger has full BAB and SD would just make him another "assassin king".
Int 16 is there for +1 skill and +1 DC compared with the usual int 14. But I still miss one skill here, and that is spot (or perhaps listen if you prefer).
